citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey - Gap Analysis Project
citeinfo.title: Cooper's Hawk (Accipiter cooperii) bCOHAx_CONUS_2001v1 Range Map

descript.abstract: This dataset represents a species known range extent for Cooper's Hawk (Accipiter cooperii) within the conterminous United States (CONUS) based on 2001 ground conditions. This range map was created by attributing sub-watershed polygons with information of a species presence, origin, seasonal and reproductive use. See Gap Analysis Project Species Range Maps at https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/5951527de4b062508e3b1e79 for more information regarding data creation and user constraints. For species specific range information, see https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/59f5ebc3e4b063d5d307e13d. This range map was edited by Nathan Tarr and Jeff Lonneker; and reviewed by Matt Rubino.
descript.purpose: GAP range maps represent a coarse representation of the total areal extent of a species or the geographic limits within which a species can be found. The known range for a species can be used to constrain the boundaries of the species distribution model and in assessments of the conservation status and/or threats within the range of a species.

idinfo.useconst: It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from the U.S. Geological Survey and not indirectly through other sources, which may have modified the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey/Core Science Analytics, Synthesis, and Libraries

cntaddr.address: North Carolina State University, Campus Box 7617

method.methdesc: In the shapefile provided here, the known range information is delineated by modified sub-watershed polygons represented in USGS Gap Analysis Hydrologic Unit Codes (DOI https://doi.org/10.5066/F7DZ0754). Each sub-watershed (n=82,717) contains information on a species origin, presence, reproductive status, and seasonal use. Seasonal known range extents used to constrain predictive habitat maps (https://doi.org/10.5066/F7V122T2) are derived for each species by excluding historic presence records and dissolving sub-watershed boundaries based on seasonal use (summer, winter, and year-round).

enttyp.enttypd: This table when linked to the USGS National Gap Analysis Project Additional Data – Hydrologic Unit Codes [HUCs] dataset can be used to produce the original range data.

attr.attrdef: Numeric code representing the individual polygons in the USGS National Gap Analysis Project Additional Data – Hydrologic Unit Codes [HUCs] dataset.

attrdomv.udom: This is a twelve digit code related to the modified Hydrologic Unit dataset used to create the ranges.

attr.attrdef: Species code for the birds for which ranges were developed.

attrdomv.udom: A six digit alphabetic code representing the class (a=amphibian, r=reptile, m=mammal, b=bird) followed by 4 letters representing genus and species, followed by an x indicating the range represents the area of occupancy for the full species. For example for the Snow Goose the code = bSNGOx.

attr.attrdef: Identifies the origin of the species at that specific location.
Code that identifies the status of a species presence in the range polygon.

edom.edomvd: Extirpated purposely (applied to introduced species only)

attr.attrdef: Code that indicates the reproductive use by the species in the range polygon.
Code indicating the seasonal use of the range polygon by the species.

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
distinfo.techpreq: Users must be able to join attribute information from a CSV file to a shapefile and query an extensive attribute file to get the mapped range for an individual species. The individual species ranges are provided as unique ScienceBase items as well.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey - Core Science Analytics, Synthesis, and Libraries

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, West 6th Avenue & Kipling, Bldg. 810, MS 302
